notesStmt.p: This poem was composed ca. 1410-1424 by Valencian author Jordi de Sant Jordi, a son of a Muslim convert and valet of the chamber of the king of the Crown of Aragon, Alfonso the Magnanimous (1396-1458). It is believed to have been dedicated to the widowed Queen Margarida de Prades (1387-1429). The poem is written in Catalan with Occitan traits. It is in versos estramps, blank verses ending in unique, sonorous, words that are also known as rims fènix. Some of these rhyme words come from the famous sestina by Occitan troubadour Arnaut Daniel. Versos estramps in fact seem to be an evolution or an innovative version of the traditional sestina.

This love poem features a sustained and multifaceted praise of the lady with attention to both her physical and moral beauty as well as a declaration of the steadfast love of the lyric voice. A dense, object-oriented imagery pervades each stanza. The text is considered the most remarkable love song of the trobar ric tradition in medieval Catalan poetry.

This poem is a unicum copied in Zaragoza, Biblioteca de la Universidad de Zaragoza, MS 210, fol. 98v-99r (the Cançoner de Saragossa). The manuscript has been digitized here: http://zaguan.unizar.es/record/535?ln=en. It contains a compilation of Catalan verse dating to 1461-1462. It is the oldest known manuscript to transmit Ausiàs March’s poetry, and an important witness to the transmission of the poetry of several other authors, including Pere Torroella and Lleonard de Sors.
de Riquer, Martí and Lola Badia, editors. Les poesies de Jordi de Sant Jordi. Tres i Quatre, 1984. This is the canonical edition and commentary of Sant Jordi’s works.
Jordi de Sant Jordi. Poesies. Edited by Aniello Fratta. Barcino, 2005. This edition makes important textual contributions and advances a debated Italianizing interpretation of Sant Jordi’s poetry.

Torró, Jaume. “El cançoner de Saragossa.” Translatar i transferir: La transmissió dels textos i el saber (1200-1500). Edited by Anna Alberni, Lola Badia i Lluís Cabré. Obrador Edèndum, 2010, pp. 379-415. This is the most up-to-date study of the songbook containing Sant Jordi’s poem.

Micó, José María. “Translating Medieval Catalan Poetry Today: Jordi de Sant Jordi and Ausiàs March.” Translation Review, vol. 87, 2013, pp. 18-29. Reflections on translating Sant Jordi’s poetry into Spanish.

Terry, Arthur. “Jordi de Sant Jordi and the Ethics of Chivalry.” Three Fifteenth-Century Valencian Poets. Department of Hispanic Studies, Queen Mary and Westfield College, 2000, pp. 24-38. Short introduction to Sant Jordi’s work in English. It contains a reading of the poem.

Albert Lloret. “The Space in the Poem (Jordi de Sant Jordi, IX & XIV).” Revealing New Perspectives: Hommages to Stephen G. Nichols from his Colleagues, Friends and Students, edited by Kevin Brownlee and Marina Brownlee, Peter Lang, 2021. Study of space in two poems by Sant Jordi.

projectDesc.p: "Underneath my forehead I carry your beautiful image" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

I have punctuated the text, regularized i/j, u/v, and segmented enclitics following modern conventions. I have only made two corrections to obvious copying errors, both accepted in modern editions: jusmetets, correcting (*iustametz) and fonch (correcting *fonchs).

app.lem: Jus lo front port vostra bella semblança,
app.rdg: Underneath my forehead I carry your beautiful image,

app.lem: de que mon cors nit e jorn fa gran festa;
app.rdg: That’s why I celebrate you, night and day;

app.lem: que, remiran la molt bella figura,
app.rdg: For, by looking at your beautiful figure,

app.lem: de vostre ffaç m’es romassa l’empremta,
app.rdg: A trace of your face has remained in me.

app.lem: que ja per mort no se’n partra la forma,
app.rdg: Its shape won’t go away when I die,

app.lem: ans, quant seray del tot fores d’est segle,
app.rdg: Instead, when I will have entirely left this earthly life,

app.lem: cels qui lo cors portaran al sepulcre,
app.rdg: Those who will bring my body to the tomb

app.lem: sobre me faç, veuran lo vostre signe.
app.rdg: Will find your sign on my face.

app.lem: Si com l’infants quant mira lo retaula
app.rdg: Like the little kid who watches the altarpiece

app.lem: e, contemplant la pintur·ab himatges,
app.rdg: And contemplates the painting and its images

app.lem: ab son net cor, no lo·n poden gens partre
app.rdg: With a pure heart, and doesn’t want to separate from it

app.lem: (tant ha plasser de l’aur qui ll’environa),
app.rdg: (So much does he enjoy the gold that surrounds it),

app.lem: atressi·m pren devan l’amoros sercle
app.rdg: That’s how I feel when I’m in front of the love circle

app.lem: de vostre cors, que de tants bens s’anrama,
app.rdg: Of your figure, for it’s embellished with so many qualities

app.lem: que, mentre·l vey, mas que Deu lo contemple;
app.rdg: That, while I’m watching it, I contemplate it better than God;

app.lem: tant hay de joy per amor qui·m penetre.
app.rdg: This love that penetrates me brings me so much joy.

app.lem: Aixi·m te pres e liatz en son carçre
app.rdg: That’s how he has me, captive and tied up, in his jail,

app.lem: amors ardents, com si·stes en hun coffre,
app.rdg: This ardent Love, as if I were inside a chest,

app.lem: tancat jus claus, e tot mon cors fos dintre,
app.rdg: Locked in, all of me inside,

app.lem: on no pusques mover per null encontre.
app.rdg: Without a chance to break out.

app.lem: Car tant es grans l’amor que us ay, e ferme,
app.rdg: So big is my love for you, and so steadfast,

app.lem: que lo meu cor no·s part punt per angoxa,
app.rdg: That my heart won’t move away, not one bit, out of anguish,

app.lem: bella, de vos, ans es ·say ferm com torres
app.rdg: From you, beautiful one, but will rather be strong as a tower

app.lem: e sol amar a vos, blanxa colomba.
app.rdg: And will only love you, white dove.

app.lem: Bella sens par, ab la pressensa noble,
app.rdg: Unmatched beauty of noble presence,

app.lem: vostre bel cors bell fech Deu sobre totas,
app.rdg: God made your pretty body superior to any other,

app.lem: gays e donos, lluu pus que fina pedre,
app.rdg: Gay and gentle, brighter than a gemstone,

app.lem: amoros, bels, plus penetrans que stella;
app.rdg: Loving, beautiful, more penetrating than a star;

app.lem: d’on, quan vos vey ab les autres en flota,
app.rdg: For, when I spot you among other people,

app.lem:
les jusmetets
Correcting iustametz. si com fay lo carvoncles,
app.rdg: You subdue them as does the carbuncle,

app.lem: que de virtuts les finas pedres passa:
app.rdg: Which surpasses the qualities of any gemstone;

app.lem: vos etz sus ley com l’estors sus l’esmirle.
app.rdg: You are above them like the goshawk is above the merlin.

app.lem: L’amor que us hay en totes les part[s] m’ascle
app.rdg: My love for you is splintering every part of me

app.lem: quan non amech pus coralment nuls homens;
app.rdg: For no one has ever loved so sincerely;

app.lem: tan fort·amor, com cesta que·l cor m’obre,
app.rdg: Such a strong love, like this one that opens my heart,

app.lem:
ne fonch
Correcting fonchs. jamays en nul cors d’hom ne arme.
app.rdg: Has never been in anyone’s body or soul.

app.lem: Mas suy torbats que no fonch Aristotills,
app.rdg: I am more upset than Aristotle ever was

app.lem: d’amor, qui m’art e mos sinch senys desferme.
app.rdg: For love, which burns me and unleashes my five senses.

app.lem: Co·l monjos bos que no·s part de la setla,
app.rdg: Like the good monk who does not leave his cell,

app.lem: no·s part mon cors da vos, tant com dits d’ungle.
app.rdg: My heart does not move away from you, like the finger from the nail.

app.lem: Ho, cors donos, net de frau e delicte,
app.rdg: Oh, gentle lady, clean of deceit and offenses,

app.lem: prenets de me pietats, bela dona,
app.rdg: Have pity on me, beautiful lady,

app.lem: e no suffrats quez aman-vos peresca,
app.rdg: And don’t allow that I die by loving you,

app.lem: pus qu·eu vos am may que nulls homs afferme,
app.rdg: For I love you more than anyone could affirm;

app.lem: per que us suppley a vos, qu·etz le bells arbres
app.rdg: That is why I beg you—since you are the handsome tree

app.lem: de tots bos fruyts, hon valors grans pren s·ombre,
app.rdg: Of all good fruits, where the high Worth rest on its shade—

app.lem: que·m retenyats en vostra valent cambre,
app.rdg: To keep me in your prized chamber,

app.lem: pus vostre suy e seray tant com visque.
app.rdg: For I am yours, and so will I be for as long as I live.

app.lem: Mos richs balays, cert, vos portats le timbre
app.rdg: My prized spinel, you certainly wear the crown

app.lem: sus quantes son e·l mundenal registre,
app.rdg: Over all women in the worldy registry

app.lem: car tots jorns naix en vos cors, e revida,
app.rdg: For every day are born in you, and revive,

app.lem: bondats, virtuts, mes qu·en Pantasilea.
app.rdg: Goodness and virtue, more than they ever did in Penthesilea.
